<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A student investigates stationary waves with an elastic cord of circular cross-section attached to a load, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 112, 771, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 291, 532, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
When the frequency of the vibrator is \(f,\) the cord vibrates with the stationary wave pattern shown. The student investigates how \(f\) varies with the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the cord.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 566, 388]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(f\) and \(A\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 396, 551, 433]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{1}{2L}\sqrt{\frac{M}{kA}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 888, 464]]<|/det|>
where \(L\) is the distance between the two nodes, \(M\) is the mass of the load and \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 710, 495]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(f\) and \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 491, 662, 510]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 816, 541]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 537, 561, 556]]<|/det|>
In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 395, 587]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 410, 616]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 348, 645]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 658, 351, 675]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 687, 447, 704]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 771, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates how the viscous force in a liquid varies with temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
The student releases a ball from the surface of the liquid in a container. The ball falls as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 144, 700, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
The student determines the speed of the ball between P and Q and measures the thermodynamic temperature \(T\) of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
Viscosity is a term used to describe the viscous forces acting in a liquid. Viscosity has the unit pascal second (Pas). The viscosity \(\eta\) of the liquid is calculated from the speed of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 715, 508]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for the same liquid at different temperatures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 571, 539]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\eta\) and \(T\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 548, 549, 577]]<|/det|>
\[\eta = H\mathrm{e}^{\left(\frac{E}{kT}\right)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 633, 600]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) and \(H\) are constants and \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 613, 144, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 667, 631]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\ln \eta\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{T}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 643, 611, 662]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 835, 917, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 866, 917, 884]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 489, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(T\) and \(\eta\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 128, 860, 415]]<|/det|>
\(T/\mathrm {K}\)\(\eta /10^{-4}\mathrm {Pas}\)\(\frac {1}{T}/10^{-3}\mathrm {K}^{-1}\)\(\ln \left(\eta /10^{-4}\mathrm {Pas}\right)\)
29212.3 ± 0.23.42
3039.8 ± 0.23.30
3118.4 ± 0.23.22
3236.8 ± 0.23.10
3355.6 ± 0.22.99
3464.8 ± 0.22.89
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 645, 448]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\ln \left(\eta /10^{-4}\mathrm {Pas}\right)\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 591, 464]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\ln \left(\eta /10^{-4}\mathrm {Pas}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 447, 920, 465]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 144, 495]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 476, 176, 495]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 472, 616, 496]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\ln \left(\eta /10^{-4}\mathrm {Pas}\right)\) against \(\frac {1}{T}/10^{-3}\mathrm {K}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 491, 410, 510]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\ln \ \eta\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 920, 510]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 523, 176, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 522, 920, 555]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 559]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 570, 180, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 567, 920, 602]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 817, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Do **not** include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 225, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
\[y\mathrm{-intercept} = .................................................... [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 185, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 257, 920, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 415, 320]]<|/det|>
